abstract.text: An abstract class that you subclass to implement app-specific services.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: only if you want to provide custom services to people. A service takes data that’s passed to it, does something to that data, and returns the results. For example, a social media service might take whatever text, images, or other content is provided to it and post them to a person’s account. Activity objects are used in conjunction with a
object, which is responsible for presenting services to people.
The system already provides support for many standard services and makes them available through the

object. For example, the standard activity view controller supports emailing data, posting items to one of a person’s social media accounts, and several other options. You don’t have to provide custom services for any of the built-in types.

This class must be subclassed before it can be used. The job of an activity object is to act on the data provided to it and to provide some meta information that iOS can display to people. For more complex services, an activity object can also display a custom user interface and use it to gather additional information from people.
When subclassing, you must always override the following methods and use them to provide information about your service:
method indicates that your subclass is able to operate on the specified data, the active
object displays your service to people. When a person selects your service, the activity view controller calls the
method followed by only one of these methods:

— Returns a view controller to present to a person. If your service requires additional input from a person, override this method and use it to return the view controller object responsible for presenting your custom UI. (You don’t need to present the view controller yourself.) After your view controller object gathers the needed input, it’s responsible for initiating the task associated with the service.
— Performs the service without displaying any additional UI. If your service doesn’t need additional input from a person, override this method and perform the task associated with the service.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An abstract class that you subclass to implement app-specific services.
A structure that describes the types of activities for which the system has built-in support.
An enumeration that defines categories of activities.
The category of the activity, which may be used to group activities in the UI.
Notifies the system that your activity object has completed its work.
An image that identifies the service to the user.
A user-readable string that describes the service.
The type of service being provided.
The view controller to present to the user.
Queries whether the service can act on the specified data items.
Performs the service when no custom view controller is provided.
Prepares your service to act on the specified data.
A proxy for data that passes to an activity view controller.
A set of methods that an activity view controller uses to retrieve the data items to act on.
A view controller that you use to offer standard services from your app.
Add custom document browser actions, activities, and bar items.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
